Marketing Intelligence New Competitors: Why Is It Important to Identify and Monitor Them? Start your free trial by Monique Ellis , Content Marketing Manager 8 Min. August 15, 2024 X Facebook Linkedin Copy link Free Website Traffic Checker Discover your competitors' strengths and leverage them to achieve your own success Analyze Traffic In today’s fast-paced world, markets are increasingly volatile, with new competitors consistently emerging to challenge established players. Rapid technological advancements lower barriers to entry, while shifting consumer preferences demand continuous innovation and adaptation. In such a dynamic environment, businesses must stay vigilant and proactive to maintain their competitive edge. So, what are the key drivers behind the rise of new market entrants? In this guide, we talk through everything from technological innovation to changing consumer behaviors, and how by understanding these factors, you can better anticipate potential threats and seize opportunities that new competitors bring. We also delve into strategies for identifying rising competitors, understanding what fuels their growth, and developing effective responses to sustain or even enhance your company’s market presence. Let’s dive in! The importance of detecting new competitors Identifying and monitoring new competitors is crucial for understanding changing market dynamics. New threats are always emerging, so businesses must remain on guard and continually adapt to maintain a competitive advantage. Here are some of the key reasons why businesses should prioritize detecting new market entrants: Maintaining market position Quickly identifying new competitors allows businesses to develop a counter-strategy – helping you to regroup quickly and protect market share. By proactively understanding and responding to competitors’ tactics, companies can position themselves as leaders in their fields. This could involve making product tweaks, ramping up marketing efforts or organizing special promotions to retain existing clients and attract new customers. Identifying opportunities Spotting gaps that new competitors fail to address can create opportunities for product differentiation and growth. If a new market entrant isn’t serving a particular area well, your business can capitalize on this by swooping in and filling the gap. Opportunities like this can help establish a unique selling proposition that sets your company apart from the competition. Improving customer retention Understanding why a customer might be lured away by a competitor helps you fine-tune products and services to better meet their needs. Analyzing competitors can also reveal weaknesses that your business can exploit to retain your best customers. Regularly reviewing customer feedback and making adjustments based on their input often leads to higher retention and reduced churn. Adapting to market changes A new entrant could often signal evolving market trends, and staying aware of these shifts is vital to remaining relevant in business. For example, the demand for eco-friendly products led to the creation of green products. Keeping an eye on trends like this allows you to adjust your product development strategy accordingly. Enhancing strategic planning Information on new entrants in the market provides invaluable knowledge for future-proofing your business strategy. It could be anything from acquisitions and partnerships to focus shifting in marketing campaigns to address emerging consumer segments. Why do new competitors emerge? New competitors can enter the marketplace for various reasons, each presenting unique challenges and opportunities for existing businesses: 1. Evolving consumer needs Changing consumer preferences opens up gaps that new entrants to the market seek to fill. For example, many startups nowadays deal in organic and natural products because this is a major trend. Trends of this nature give new entrants opportunities to make their way into the industry and attract consumers seeking something new or specific. 2. Technological advances Innovations often cannibalize prevailing markets. Just think about how the evolution of streaming services is changing the shape of the entertainment industry. Fintech is another good example as it has disrupted existing banks with the ability to perform bank operations much faster and more effectively, changing customer expectations immensely. 3. Regulatory changes Deregulation enables newer and smaller firms to compete with the established players in certain industries. For example, deregulation of the telecommunication sector allows new companies to easily enter and offer services that effectively rival products offered by more established firms. With this kind of regulatory environment, new players have been set to take advantage of this newfound flexibility. 4. Globalization International markets have opened the door for new players. Spotify, which is now available in 184 markets worldwide, and Netflix, with over 260 million subscribers across the globe, are examples of companies that were able to get a foothold in emerging regional markets, which enabled them to utilize local market experience in some instances to give them a strong competitive edge against any national entity. Global entrants usually establish new angles of thinking and this increases the diversity of the competitive setting. 5. Shifting cultural trends The new direct-to-consumer brands rise as a function of cultural changes toward personalization of customer experience. Companies such as Warby Parker and Casper have been gaining ground due to differentiated customer experiences and direct engagement with their consumers. Learning how to spot trends and take advantage of them allows businesses to remain relevant and competitive. Ways to identify new competitors in your market Identifying new competitors requires monitoring various market touchpoints. Here are some commonly-used techniques to help you stay updated: Analyze the competitive landscape This involves making assessments through comprehensive tools that plot out the position of one’s competitors. Similarweb’s Market Quadrant Analysis graph aims at categorizing firms on the basis of market position or competitive strength: 1. Leaders Established companies are very dominant in different areas. They invest heavily on R&D (research and development) and market development to support their leading position. This may usually encompass product range expansion with the need for constant innovations to keep ahead of the competition. 2. Challengers The new competitors in the market have a great value proposition but a lesser market share. Their challenges to the status quo are most often by aggressive marketing and solution innovation. They tend to be very agile, and able to quickly pivot in light of market demands. 3. Visionaries These are innovative companies with fast-growing strategies. These types of firms usually put a lot of effort into technological innovation and niche markets. They are known to foresee future trends and to prepare for a blowout in upcoming opportunities. 4. Niche players Niche players represent companies that are focused on a special set of market needs. The understanding that they have for niche segments gives them a better position to offer solutions that larger players will overlook. Find rising players Emerging competitors are often the first signal of upcoming market shifts. In a highly competitive environment, early identification of new players can be the key to competitive advantage. The use of comprehensive market intelligence tools, such as Similarweb’s Market Players, allows companies to keep tabs on patent filings, new launches, and funding announcements. This can keep your organization in a very advantageous position. Detailed market data helps you anticipate the moves of potential competitors and adopt the appropriate strategies. Emerging companies are, most of the time, an indicator of changing market dynamics and can deeply impact existing companies. Some companies take advantage of rapid growth by exploiting market gaps, which is why keeping a close watch on new entrants is important for strategic adaptability. It is also important to gain an upper hand by gleaning insights from patent filings, product launches, and funding announcements. Discover organic search competitors Search engines are very powerful when it comes to highlighting new entrants in the market. Keyword trend tracking and search visibility allow companies to monitor potential competitors and their fast-growing online presence. Similarweb’s Search Competitor tool helps in getting much more detailed information about organic search traffic and learning how new entrants grab the attention of their target audiences – by focusing content on high-intent keywords. Keyword tracking uncovers crucial information about new competitors. With Similarweb’s superior data on search traffic and competitor online presence, you can understand how these new competitors enter the marketplace with those channels, ensuring you don’t miss any opportunities while holding your ground in the marketplace. Social listening Social media is full of information regarding competitor activities and market trends, and with continuous monitoring, you’ll get a goldmine of valuable insights. For example, joining industry-related LinkedIn groups and following influential voices on X (formerly Twitter) will help you pinpoint emerging competitors. You’ll be better prepared with competitive intelligence data with respect to strategy fine-tuning and marketplace leadership. Monitor your competitors Similarweb’s Competitive Tracker is an excellent way to keep track of the competition. This tool draws data from a host of your chosen competitors to help you monitor their activities over time. Track competitors’ website traffic This tool enables you to get information on the sources of web traffic, user engagement metrics, and performance on the web for your competitors. These metrics offer the most up-to-date data on their digital strategies across multiple channels (from organic and paid to social), helping you benchmark yourself against them: Identify marketing strategies This will give you an insight into your competitors’ marketing campaigns and their keyword strategies. You will be able to determine how they acquire customers and how they are able to keep them to fine-tune your own campaigns. Benchmark your performance Comparing your metrics against those of your competitors helps identify areas for improvement. These insights keep your business aligned with or even ahead of industry standards. For instance, if you’re Netflix, you’d want to analyze key user engagement metrics for your streaming service compared to competitors like Disney+, Hulu, and Amazon Prime, to understand where viewers are spending more time and why: Luckily, with Similarweb’s Competitive Tracker, you have a single platform to monitor your competitors’ performance over time. This gives you the ability to quickly uncover data-driven insights into their strategies and performance, enabling your business to respond effectively to competitive moves. Staying ahead in a competitive landscape The bottom line: to stay competitive, you need to remain fresh. That means regularly monitoring new market entrants and adjusting your strategies accordingly. Start your free trial FAQs How do new competitors change existing market dynamics? New entrants can realign markets by responding to shifts in customer preferences or introducing innovative products, often forcing established firms to rethink their strategies. What steps should businesses take in response to new competitors? Start with a thorough competitor analysis, then innovate and refine your products or services to meet or exceed market expectations. Are there specific tools to help track competitor activities effectively? Yes, tools like Similarweb’s Competitive Tracker, industry reports, and social media monitoring provide ongoing insights into competitor strategies and activities. How frequently should the competitive analysis be reviewed? Ideally, competitive analysis should be reviewed quarterly, though frequency may vary depending on industry dynamics. Regular reviews ensure strategies remain relevant and innovative. Can small businesses compete effectively with new, larger market entrants? Absolutely. Small businesses can leverage agility, niche focus, and superior customer service to compete effectively, using insights from competitor analysis to craft counter-strategies. by Monique Ellis Content Marketing Manager Monique, with 7 years in data storytelling, enjoys crafting content and exploring new places.
